title-group.article-title: Development of a Theranostic Agent for Bone Metastases: Integration of Nuclear Medicine Imaging and Boron Neutron Capture Therapy (BNCT)

contrib-group.aff: 1 Graduate School of Medical Sciences, 12858Kanazawa University, Kanazawa, Ishikawa 920-1192, Japan

abstract.p: Boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) is one of the promising cancer treatment methods with 10B-labeled compounds and neutron irradiation. The 10B­(n,α)7Li reaction produces a 7Li nucleus and an α-particle with high linear energy transfer, which are responsible for the therapeutic effects. We hypothesized that BNCT could effectively treat bone metastases by selectively accumulating 10B at metastatic lesion sites. In this study, we designed, synthesized, and evaluated [nat/67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 ([nat/67Ga]6), a compound integrating closo-dodecaborate for BNCT, a [nat/67Ga]­Ga-DOTA derivative for nuclear imaging, and D11, an aspartic acid peptide, for bone targeting. [67Ga]6 and its precursor 5, which lacks gallium coordination, showed comparable biodistribution in normal mice, with high bone uptake and minimal off-target accumulation. These results support the potential of [nat/67/68Ga]6 as an effective theranostic agent for bone metastases.

institution-wrap.institution: Japan Society for the Promotion of Science
NOVARTIS Foundation (Japan) for the Promotion of Science

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Boron neutron capture therapy (BNCT) is a promising cancer treatment that relies on the selective uptake of boron-10 (10B) labeled compounds into cancer cells, followed by neutron irradiation. , Upon exposure to thermal neutrons, 10B undergoes a nuclear reaction, 10B­(n, α)7Li, producing an α-particle and a 7Li nucleus. Both particles are characterized by high linear energy transfer (LET) and relative biological effectiveness (RBE), making them highly cytotoxic. With ranges of approximately 9 and 4 μm, respectively, near or below the diameter of a single cell, these particles enable the selective killing of cancer cells while minimizing damage to surrounding normal tissues. For BNCT to be effective, high and selective accumulation of 10B in the target cells is essential.

Bone, rich in growth factors, provides a favorable environment for cancer proliferation. Consequently, bone metastases frequently occurred in patients with breast, prostate, and lung cancers. , As bone metastases progress, complications such as fractures, pain, and spinal cord compression arise, significantly diminishing patients’ quality of life. Current clinical treatments for bone metastases include surgery, radiotherapy, hormone therapy, chemotherapy, and targeted pharmaceuticals, such as zoledronic acid and denosumab, that interrupt the “vicious cycle” of bone destruction. However, these treatments primarily aim to prevent fractures and alleviate pain, rather than eliminate metastases. , Bone-seeking radiopharmaceuticals labeled with β– emitting radionuclides, such as [89Sr]­SrCl2 (Metastron) and [153Sm]­Sm-EDTMP (Quadramet), offer only palliative relief. In contrast, [223Ra]­RaCl2 (Xofigo), an α-emitter, not only relieves pain but also prolongs overall survival and delays the onset of skeletal-related events in castration resistant prostate cancer patients. −
Inspired by the efficacy of [223Ra]­RaCl2, we hypothesized that BNCTusing bone-targeting 10B-labeled compoundscould be an effective treatment strategy for certain types of bone metastases.

We have developed various radiolabeled bone-seeking agents using bisphosphonates −
and acidic oligopeptides −
as bone carriers. Our previous study demonstrated that [67Ga]­Ga-1,4,7,10-tetraazacyclododecane-1,4,7,10-tetraacetic acid (DOTA)-D11 exhibited excellent biodistribution as a bone-imaging probe. Additionally, radiolabeled combination peptides, such as [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-D11-c­(RGDfK) (Figure a), [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-D11-TATE (Figure b), and [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-D11-PSMA617 (Figure c), also showed high bone uptake. −
These findings indicate that D11 retains bone affinity even when conjugated to moderately sized molecules. We also developed closo-dodecaborate-(Ga-DOTA)-c­(RGDfK) (Figure d), a probe with a structure compatible for both BNCT and PET diagnostics. It features a closo-dodecaborate ([B12H12]2–) boron cluster with multiple 10B molecules, a [68Ga]­Ga-DOTA derivative as a stable 68Ga (T 1/2: 68 min) complex for PET imaging, and an arginine-glycine-aspartic acid (RGD) peptide for tumor targeting. This probe showed promising potential as a theranostic agent.

In this study, we hypothesized that [nat/68Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11, which contains closo-dodecaborate for BNCT, [nat/68Ga]­Ga-DOTA complex for PET imaging, and D11 for bone affinity, could serve as a theranostic agent for patients with bone metastases (Figure ). Although our ultimate goal was to develop a 68Ga-labeled PET agent, 67Ga (T 1/2: 3.3 days) was used instead, owing to its easier handling during synthesis and evaluation, and synthesized [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11.

caption.p: Concept of the drug design in this study; a structure of [nat/68Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 ([nat/68Ga]6).

sec.title: Materials
sec.p:
1H nuclear magnetic resonance (NMR) spectra were recorded on JEOL JNM-ECS400 (JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) operating at 400 MHz. Chemical shifts for 1H NMR were reported in ppm units relative to residual solvent signal (2.50 ppm in DMSO-d
6 ). Electrospray ionization mass spectra (ESI-MS) were obtained using an LCMS-9030 (Shimadzu Co., Kyoto, Japan). [67Ga]­Ga-citrate (Nihon Medi-Physics Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) was converted to [67Ga]­GaCl3 using Sep-Pak Silica Plus Light Cartridge (Waters Co., Ltd., Milford, MA, USA) as described in previous reports. , Sodium dodecahydrododecaborate was purchased from Katchem. Ltd. (Prague, Czech). 2-Chlorotrityl chloride resin (Watanabe Chemical Industries, Ltd., Hiroshima, Japan), Fmoc-l-Asp­(OtBu)-OH and Fmoc-l-Lys­(Boc)-OH (AmBeed, Arlington Heights, IL, USA) were used for the peptide synthesis. Cyclen was obtained from BLD pharmatech Ltd. (Shanghai, China). N,N-Diisopropylethylamine (DIPEA) was obtained from Nacalai Tesque (Kyoto, Japan). 1,3-Diisopropylcarbodiimide (DIPCDI) and 1-hydroxybenzotriazole hydrate (HOBt) were obtained from Kokusan Chemical Co., Ltd. (Tokyo, Japan). Other reagents were of reagent grade and used as received.

sec.title: Preparation of [nat/67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 ([nat/67Ga]6)
sec.p: Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 (6) and [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 ([67Ga]6) were synthesized following the procedure shown in Scheme .

fn.label: a
fn.p: Reagents: (a) EDCI·HCl, CH2Cl2, rt, (b) TEA, DMF, rt, (c) TFA, H2O, TIS, rt, (d) TEA, DMF, rt, (e) Ga­(NO3)3, 3 M ammonium acetate buffer (pH 5.0), 40 °C or [67Ga]­GaCl3, 3 M ammonium acetate buffer (pH 5.0), 80 °C

sec.title: Bis­(2,5-dioxopyrrolidin-1-yl) terephthalate (1)
sec.p: Terephthalic acid (0.5 g, 3.0 mmol), N-hydroxysuccinimide (0.8 g, 7.3 mmol), and 1-ethyl-3-(3-dimethylaminopropyl)­carbodiimide hydrochloride (EDCI·HCl) (1.4 g, 7.5 mmol) were dissolved in 30 mL of dichloromethane. After 3 h stirring of the solution at room temperature, the solution was concentrated in vacuo and the residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography eluted with a gradient mobile phase of hexane/ethyl acetate, 50/50 to 0/100 to afford 1 (0.3 g, 30%) as a colorless powder.

sec.title: Compound 3
sec.p: To a solution of dodecaborate derivative 2 (20 mg, 41 μmol), which was synthesized according to a previous report, in 3 mL of N,N-dimethylformamide (DMF), 1 (74 mg, 0.21 mmol) and triethylamine (TEA) (23 μL, 0.16 mmol) were added. After the mixture was stirred for 18 h at room temperature, the solution was concentrated in vacuo. The residue was purified by silica gel column chromatography eluted with a gradient mobile phase of ethyl acetate/acetonitrile, 100/0 to 0/100 to afford 3 (24 mg, 80%) as a colorless powder.
HRMS (ESI–) m/z: [M-H]− calcd for C16H27B12N2O7: 489.3013; found, 489.3032.

sec.title: DOTA-KD11 (4)
sec.p: Compound 4 was manually prepared using the conventional Fmoc-based solid-phase synthesis method. Namely, after binding Fmoc-l-Asp­(OtBu)-OH to 2-chlorotrityl-chloride resin, the target peptide was synthesized using Fmoc-l-Asp­(OtBu)-OH, Fmoc-l-Lys­(Boc)-OH, and DOTA-tris­(tBu ester) according to a previously reported procedure. The peptide was cleaved from the resin and the protecting groups were removed using a mixture of 95% trifluoroacetic acid (TFA), 2.5% water, and 2.5% triisopropylsilane (TIS). The crude peptide was purified by reversed-phase (RP)-HPLC on a Cosmosil 5C18-AR-II column (20 × 250 mm) at a flow rate of 12 mL/min, employing a gradient elution from 5% to 20% methanol in water containing 0.1% TFA for 20 min. The solvent was removed by lyophilization to yield 4 (14.2 mg, 7.9%) as a colorless powder.
HRMS (ESI+) m/z: [M+2H]2+ calcd for C66H95N17O42: 899.7983; found, 899.8000.

sec.title: DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 (5)
sec.p: Compound 3 (6.2 mg, 8.4 μmol), 4 (5.0 mg, 2.8 μmol), and TEA (80 μL, 0.58 mmol) were dissolved in 0.4 mL of DMF. After 3 h stirring at room temperature, the solution was concentrated in vacuo and purified by RP-HPLC on a Cosmosil 5C18-AR-II column (10 × 150 mm) at a flow rate of 4 mL/min, employing a gradient elution from 15% to 45% methanol in water containing 0.1% TFA for 20 min. The solvent was removed by lyophilization to yield 5 (2.3 mg, 38%) as a colorless powder.

sec.title: Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 (6)
sec.p: Compound 5 (1.6 mg, 0.7 μmol) was dissolved in 3 M ammonium acetate buffer (pH 5.0), and Ga­(NO3)3 (1.9 μg, 7.4 μmol) was added to the solution. After 2 h stirring at 40 °C, the mixture was purified by RP-HPLC on a Cosmosil 5C18-AR-II column (4.6 × 150 mm) at a flow rate of 1 mL/min, employing a gradient elution from 15% to 55% methanol in water containing 0.1% TFA for 20 min. The solvent was removed by lyophilization to yield 6 (0.45 mg, 27%) as a colorless powder.
MS (ESI–) m/z: [M]2– calcd for C78H116B12GaN18O46: 1119.8874; found, 1119.8863.

sec.title: [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 ([67Ga]6)
sec.p: Compound 5 (41 μg, 19 nmol) was dissolved in a mixed solution consisting of 40 μL of 3 M ammonium acetate buffer (pH 5.0) and 40 μL of [67Ga]­GaCl3 (1.1 MBq) in 0.1 M aqueous HCl. After reaction at 80 °C for 15 min, [67Ga]6 was purified and analyzed by RP-HPLC on a Cosmosil 5C18-AR-II column (4.6 × 150 mm) at the same conditions as those used for 6.

sec.title: Hydroxyapatite Binding Assay
sec.p: A hydroxyapatite-binding assay was conducted according to previously reported procedures. In brief, hydroxyapatite beads (Bio-Gel; Bio-Rad, Hercules, CA, USA) were suspended in Tris/HCl-buffered saline (50 mM, pH 7.4) at concentrations of 1, 2.5, 10, and 25 mg/mL. Solutions of [67Ga]6 were prepared at a final ligand concentration of 19.5 μM by adding 5, instead of 6. Each [67Ga]6 solution (200 μL) was mixed with the hydroxyapatite suspension (200 μL) and gently shaken at room temperature for 1 h. The mixtures were centrifuged at 10,000g for 5 min, and the radioactivity of the supernatants was measured using an auto well gamma counter (ARC-8001, ALOKA Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). Control experiments were performed in the same manner without hydroxyapatite beads. The hydroxyapatite binding ratios were calculated asHydroxyapatitebinding(%)=(1−[radioactivityofsamplesupernatant]/[radioactivityofcontrolsupernatant])×100

sec.title: In Vitro Stability Experiment
sec.p: The stability experiment of [67Ga]6 in murine plasma was evaluated with slight modifications to previous reported methods. , Briefly, [67Ga]6 was mixed with murine plasma at a 1:9 ratio (v/v) and incubated at 37 °C for 10 min and 1 h. An equal volume of ice-cold acetonitrile with 0.1% trichloroacetic acid was added, and the mixture was kept on ice for 15 min. After centrifugation at 1,700g for 15 min at 4 °C, the supernatant was filtered through a 0.45-μm membrane filter. The filtrates were subsequently subjected to RP-HPLC analysis, as described above, to determine the radiochemical purity.

sec.title: Animals
sec.p: All animal experiments were performed in compliance with the Guidelines for the Care and Use of Laboratory Animals of Kanazawa University and were approved by the Committee on Animal Experimentation of Kanazawa University (AP20–012 and AP22–028–01). The animals were maintained under controlled conditions (23 °C, 12 h light/dark cycle) with free access to food and water.

sec.title: A Biodistribution Experiment of [67Ga]6
sec.p: A biodistribution experiment was conducted after an intravenous injection of [67Ga]6 solution diluted in saline (37 kBq/100 μL) to 6-week-old male ddY mice (27–32 g, Japan SLC, Inc., Hamamatsu, Japan). Four mice at each time point were sacrificed at 10 min, 1 h, and 3 h postinjection. Tissues of interest were excised and weighed. The whole left femur was taken as a representative bone sample, and its radioactivity was measured using an auto well gamma counter (ARC-8001, ALOKA Co., Ltd.). The counts were corrected for background radiation and physical decay during measurement.

To investigate the effect of ligand amount on the biodistribution of [67Ga]6, 515 μg (0.4 mmol) or 2.06 mg (1.6 mmol) of (Asp)11 was administered just before [67Ga]6 injection, and the biodistribution at 1 h postinjection was evaluated using the same method as described above. Ideally, 6 should be used as the ligand; however, due to synthetic limitations, (Asp)11, which is the moiety responsible for the target binding of 6, was used instead.

sec.title: Analysis of Urine Samples
sec.p: Urine samples were collected from the bladder of 6-week-old male ddY mice (27–32 g, Japan SLC, Inc.) under anesthesia at 1 h after intravenous injection of [67Ga]6 (0.72 MBq/100 μL). The urine samples were filtered through a 0.45-μm filter followed by RP-HPLC analysis with a Cosmosil 5C18-AR-II column (4.6 × 150 mm) at a flow rate of 1 mL/min with a gradient mobile phase of 12% to 35% methanol in water with 0.1% TFA for 20 min.

sec.title: Determination of Boron Concentration in a Biodistribution Experiment of 5
sec.p: A biodistribution experiment was performed after an intravenous administration of 418.9 μg (25 μg as boron) of DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 (5) solution diluted in saline (100 μL) to 6-week-old male ddY mice (27–32 g, Japan SLC, Inc.). The injected dose of 419 μg corresponds to approximately 14 mg/kg (833 μg/kg as boron), assuming an average mouse body weight of about 30 g. Mice were sacrificed at 1 h postinjection. Tissues of interest were removed and weighed. Complete right and left femurs were isolated as representative bone samples. Each tissue was ashed with 500 μL of 60% nitric acid at 110 °C for 48 h, and 500 μL of Indium standard solution (In 1000) (Fujifilm Wako Pure Chemicals Co., Ltd., Osaka, Japan) diluted to 200 ppb was added as an internal standard. After the solution was diluted with water to 5 mL, the solution was diluted with 20 ppb of indium standard solution in 6% nitric acid to 20 mL. The boron concentration in the solution was determined with an Inductively Coupled Plasma Optical Emission Spectroscopy (ICP-OES) (iCAP Pro XP Duo, Thermo Fisher Scientific, Waltham, MA, USA). ICP standard solution B (Kanto Chemical Co., Ltd., Tokyo, Japan) was used for the calibration curve. The boron concentration in each organ was expressed as a percentage of the injected boron dose in 5 per tissue weight (%ID/g).

sec.title: SPECT/CT Imaging and Data Reconstruction
sec.p: SPECT/CT imaging of [67Ga]6 in a normal mouse was carried out using a small animal SPECT system (VECTor/CT, MIlabs, Houten, The Netherlands). SPECT acquisition was conducted 3 h after intravenous injection of [67Ga]6 (approximately 3.9 MBq). Data acquisition, reconstruction, and imaging analysis were performed according to a previous report.

sec.title: Statistical Evaluation
sec.p: The results of biodistribution experiments of [67Ga]6 and 5 were compared using unpaired Student’s t test. A p-value of less than 0.05 was considered statistically significant.

sec.title: Probe Design and Synthesis
sec.p: In probe design, although it was possible to introduce radioiodine into the boron cluster instead of a [67/68Ga]­Ga-DOTA complex, we selected the Ga-DOTA strategy for the following reasons: (1) The product labeled with a [67/68Ga]­Ga-DOTA complex under optimized conditions can often be used without purification, which simplifies the procedure and makes it more suitable for clinical use compared with radioiodinated compounds. (2) Radioiodination of dodecaborate structures could generate isomeric mixtures, complicating the synthesis and purification of a single defined compound, although introducing an alternative site for radioiodination may help avoid this issue. (3) Incorporation of a Ga-DOTA complex enhances the water solubility of the compound, thereby reducing nonspecific accumulation and off-target radioactivity.

Precursor 5, nonradioactive gallium complex 6, and 67Ga complex [67Ga]6 were synthesized as shown in Scheme . Initial attempts utilized N,N’-disuccinimidyl glutarate as a linker between 2-(2-methoxyethoxy)­ethan-1-amino-closo-dodecaborate and the ε-amino group of lysine in 4. However, this resulted in a highly hydrophilic precursor with low UV absorption, which was undesirable for HPLC analysis and purification. To address this, we employed 1, a bis-NHS ester with a benzene ring, as the linker. Precursor 5 was obtained in a 3% overall yield and high purity (Figure. S1) after RP-HPLC purification. [67Ga]6 was synthesized with a radiochemical yield of 44.0 ± 1.2% and radiochemical purity exceeding 95%. The identity of [67Ga]6 was confirmed by comparing its retention time with that of 6. Chromatograms of [67Ga]6 and 6 analyzed by RP-HPLC are shown in Figure .

caption.p: RP-HPLC chromatograms of (a) [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 ([67Ga]6) and (b) Ga-DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 (6). HPLC conditions: a flow rate of 1.0 mL/min with a gradient elution from 15% to 55% methanol in water containing 0.1% TFA for 20 min.

sec.title: Hydroxyapatite Binding Assay
sec.p: The hydroxyapatite binding affinity of [67Ga]6 is shown in Figure . The binding rate increased in a concentration-dependent manner, indicating strong affinity for hydroxyapatite.

caption.p: Hydroxyapatite binding assay. Binding ratios of [67Ga]6 to hydroxyapatite beads. Data are expressed as the mean ± SD for three or four samples.

sec.title: Stability of [67Ga] In Vitro
sec.p: In vitro stability analysis of [67Ga]6 in murine plasma at 37 °C demonstrated that [67Ga]6 was considerably stable, with radiochemical purities after 10 min and 1 h being of 95.7 ± 1.1% and 94.9 ± 0.4%, respectively. These findings indicate that under physiological conditions, [67Ga]6 maintains its structure and could enable the transportation of boron to bone metastasis sites as the target tissue without substantial degradation.

sec.title: Biodistribution of [67Ga]6 in Normal Mice
sec.p: The biodistribution of [67Ga]6 in normal mice is presented in Figure . [67Ga]6 exhibited high accumulation in bone and minimal accumulation in nontarget tissues, besides kidneys, which are involved in excretion. Although the bone accumulation of [67Ga]6 was slightly lower than that of [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-D11 and [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-d11 (as observed in our previous studies , ), the overall biodistribution pattern was similar. Notably, [67Ga]6 exhibited greater bone accumulation than previously reported hybrid compounds such as [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-D11-c­(RGDfK) (Figure a), [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-D11-TATE (Figure b), and [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-D11-PSMA617 (Figure c). ,, In these hybrids, the tumor-targeting moieties, such as the RGD peptide, octreotide analog, and PSMA ligand, may hinder binding to hydroxyapatite, as the D11 component may be less accessible owing to its position between the Ga-DOTA complex and the tumor-targeting units. In comparison, the branched structure of [67Ga]6 facilitates better access of D11 to hydroxyapatite, decreasing potential steric hindrance.

caption.p: Biodistribution at 10 min, 1 h, and 3 h postinjection of [67Ga]6 in normal mice. S. Intestine and L. Intestine mean small intestine and large intestine, respectively. *Expressed as %ID.

sec.title: Analysis of Urine Samples
sec.p: The typical chromatogram of the urine sample of normal mice after injection of [67Ga]6 is presented in Figure S4. Although hydrophilic metabolites were observed in the urine samples, it was assumed that [67Ga]6 was not metabolized in the blood immediately after injection because [67Ga]6 was stable in murine plasma in vitro and that boron was delivered to the bone after injection of DOTA-K­(ε-closo-dodecaborate)­D11 (5). In a previous study, the ratio of the intact complex in the urine samples after injection of [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-(d-Asp)14 (85.8% ± 17.4%) was significantly higher than that of [67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-(l-Asp)14 (55.0% ± 13.9%). However, the difference barely affected their bone accumulation.

sec.title: Biodistribution of 5 via ICP-OES in Normal Mice
sec.p: Figure presents a comparison of the biodistribution of 5 and [67Ga]6 at 1 h postinjection in normal mice. Data, expressed as %ID/g of 5 and [67Ga]6 in each tissue, were calculated using the boron concentration determined via ICP-OES and the radioactivity of 67Ga was measured using a γ-counter, respectively.

caption.p: Biodistribution of [67Ga]6 and 5 in normal mice at 1 h postinjection. Data were calculated using boron concentration determined by ICP-OES and radioactivity of 67Ga measured by a γ-counter, respectively. S. Intestine and L. Intestine mean small intestine and large intestine, respectively. *Expressed as %ID. # p < 0.001 vs [67Ga]6.

sec.p: Initially, we planned to compare the boron distribution of 6 with the radioactivity distribution of [67Ga]6 in each tissue. However, because of the challenges in synthesizing a sufficient quantity of 6 for this study, we evaluated 5, a precursor lacking gallium coordination with DOTA, as an alternative. In our previous study, we compared the biodistribution profiles of Ga-DOTA-conjugated RGD peptide ([67Ga]­Ga-DOTA-c­[RGDf­(4-I)­K]) and DOTA-conjugated RGD peptide (DOTA-[125I]­c­[RGDf­(4-I)­K]) and found them to be similar irrespective of Ga coordination. Based on these results, we hypothesized that the biodistribution of 5 would be similar to that of 6, with only minimal differences.

The aim of this study was to develop theranostic compounds that combine BNCT and PET imaging. A PET probe labeled with 68Ga, which serves as an alternative to the 67Ga-labeled compound used for SPECT in this study, is expected to function as a companion diagnostic agent for a BNCT drug. In other words, it is crucial that [67Ga]6 and 6 exhibit equivalent pharmacokinetics in vivo. Comparison of the pharmacokinetics of BNCT drugs and PET probes involves two key considerations. First, while boron (10B) kinetics is important in BNCT, the kinetics of the radioisotope is visualized in PET. Although the chemical structures are identical and equivalent pharmacokinetics are anticipated, discrepancies may arise if the complex is unstableleading to in vivo release of the radiometalor if the metabolites of the boron-containing portion are different from those of the radioisotope-containing portion. In such cases, the pharmacokinetics would not be equivalent. The second consideration is that the doses of BNCT drugs and PET probes are substantially different. PET probes are typically administered in tracer doses, which are considerably small, while BNCT agents (e.g., [10B]­boronophenylalanine (BPA)) are administered in high doses as a high boron concentration is required at the target lesion site. This difference could lead to variations in pharmacokinetics and accumulation at the target site because high doses may cause saturation of certain targets, such as receptors. However, the target in this study is bone, specifically the hydroxyapatite at bone metastasis sites, which possesses a large binding capacity and does not get easily saturated. Therefore, even at higher doses, the accumulation rate of the BNCT compound at the lesion site is expected to be maintained. Indeed, the bone accumulation and overall biodistribution of [67Ga]6 and 5 were generally equivalent, indicating that [67/68Ga]6 could serve as a companion diagnostic agent for 5 or 6 in BNCT. However, whether the observed differences in intestinal accumulation result from the variations in stoichiometry or subtle chemical differences remains to be determined. However, when (Asp)11 (515 μg or 2.06 mg per mouse) was administered in excessive amounts instead of 6 immediately before the injection of [67Ga]6, the accumulation of [67Ga]6 in the bone decreased in (Asp)11 dose-dependent manner (Figure S3 and Table S3). The results are attributed to the greater affinity of (Asp)11 for hydroxyapatite compared with that of [67Ga]6, probably due to steric hindrance. If molar equivalents of 6 to (Asp)11 (515 μg or 2.06 mg) were administered and if 6 has the same affinity for bone as (Asp)11, 2.00 and 4.50 ppm would accumulate in bone, respectively, as per calculations. These values are lower than the accumulation level (>20 ppm in tumors) generally required for effective BNCT. However, the values of 2.00 and 4.50 ppm are likely to be underestimations because the affinity of (Asp)11 for bone is expected to be higher than that of 6. Moreover, these values represent the average accumulation in the normal femur, whereas bone metastasis sites as the target generally exhibit higher accumulation of bone-seeking agents than normal bone. Thus, 6 may be sufficient for clinical application.

sec.title: SPECT Imaging in Normal Mice
sec.p: Figure shows a SPECT image acquired 3 h postinjection of [67Ga]6. [67Ga]6 demonstrated high accumulation in bone, particularly in the joint regions, while exhibiting minimal uptake in nontarget tissues. Radioactivity was also observed in the bladder, indicating that [67Ga]6 is primarily excreted through the renal–bladder–urinary pathway.

caption.p: A representative coronal maximal intensity projection (MIP) SPECT/CT fusion image at 3 h postinjection of [67Ga]6.

sec.p: The pronounced bone uptake of [67Ga]6 is attributable to its high affinity for hydroxyapatite. Similar to other hydroxyapatite-targeted, bone-seeking radiopharmaceuticals, [67Ga]6 is expected to accumulate preferentially at sites of active bone remodeling, particularly those with elevated osteoblastic activity. The knee joint in mice is known to exhibit elevated osteoblastic activity, likely accounting for the substantial accumulation of [67Ga]6 observed in this region. In our previous study, [186Re]­Re-MAG3-conjugated bisphosphonate, which possesses high affinity for hydroxyapatite, demonstrated high uptake in knee joints and a bone metastasis site of a rat model. These findings collectively indicate that [67/68Ga]6 may serve as a promising candidate for targeting osteoblastic bone metastases, and as a noninvasive imaging tool for evaluating the distribution and accumulation of its therapeutic counterpart, namely, [10B]6, for use in BNCT.

A recent study demonstrated the therapeutic efficacy of BNCT using [10B]­BPA in a mouse model of metastatic spinal tumors. In this study, the BPA-BNCT group showed significantly prolonged survival compared with both untreated and neutron-only groups (vs untreated, p = 0.0015; vs neutron-only, p = 0.0104, log-rank test), highlighting the therapeutic potential of targeted BNCT for metastatic lesions. BPA is known to selectively accumulate in tumor cells via the L-type amino acid transporter 1 (LAT1), while 6 targets hydroxyapatite, a major component of the bone matrix. The lack of interaction between these two independent and noncompetitive mechanisms supports the feasibility of a dual-agent BNCT strategywherein BPA and 6 deliver boron to complementary targets within the tumor microenvironment, namely tumor cells and osteoblastic lesions at bone metastasis sites. An appropriate bone metastasis model is currently under development to validate this hypothesis, and it will be used in our future studies.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: In this study, we successfully designed and synthesized [nat/67Ga]6, a novel theranostic probe that integrates BNCT with nuclear medicine imaging for the treatment of bone metastases. Biodistribution experiments and SPECT imaging revealed that [67Ga]6 exhibited high accumulation in bone tissue, particularly in the knee joints, with minimal uptake in nontarget organs. Moreover, the biodistribution pattern of [67Ga]6 closely resembled that of 5, the precursor lacking gallium coordination of 6. These findings indicate that [nat/67/68Ga]6 holds substantial potential as an effective theranostic agent for the diagnosis and treatment of bone metastases.

ack.p: This work was partially funded by the Japan Society for the Promotion of Science through Grants-in-Aid for Scientific Research (21H02867), The NOVARTIS Foundation (Japan) for the Promotion of Science, Kobayashi Foundation for Cancer Research, and The Naito Foundation.

notes.p:
The Supporting Information is available free of charge at https://pubs.acs.org/doi/10.1021/acs.molpharmaceut.5c00572.
A HPLC chromatogram of 5, in vitro stability of [67Ga]6 in murine plasma, analysis of [67Ga]6 in urine, detailed biodistribution data, 1H NMR spectrum of 1, and MS spectra of 3-6 (PDF)
K.T. and Y.A. contributed equally to this work.
The authors declare no competing financial interest.
